did.unittitle: Printed Publicity sheet for the Tietjens series

scopecontent.p: Publicity sheet for the first three novels of the "Tietjens Tetralogy:: "Some Do Not", "No More Parades," and "A Man Could Stand Up". With a handwritten message: "Please return to Stella Bowen, Green End, Purleigh, Essex."

did.unittitle: TM "Professor's Progress: Synopsis"

scopecontent.p: Synopsis of Ford's last work in progress, an uncompleted novel. Includes a title page with the provisional title: "Bullen." Harvey Civ(11)

did.unittitle: TM "Professor's Progress"

scopecontent.p: First typed draft with numerous corrections and additions. Probably in Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: AMS "Professor's Progress"

scopecontent.p: Second version draft with corrections and additions. Signed by Ford and inscribed to Janice Biala.

did.unittitle: TM "Professor's Progress"

scopecontent.p: Typescript copy; relatively clean.

did.unittitle: TM "Professor's Progress"

scopecontent.p: Second typescript draft with numerous corrections. Probably in Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: TM & AM "Professor's Progress"

scopecontent.p: Third typescript version with copy. Numerous corrections and additions as well as a hand-written page.

did.unittitle: TM "Provenance" pp. 1-100

scopecontent.p: The first hundred pages of a heavily corrected typescript, with a holograph version of the first page that includes a sketch of the travel route Ford's book is following. Used as the printer's copy of the American edition of "Provence" published by Lippincott in 1935.

did.unittitle: TM "Provenance" pp. 101-200

scopecontent.p: The second hundred pages of a corrected typescript.

did.unittitle: TM "Provenance" pp. 201-300

scopecontent.p: The third hundred pages of a corrected typescript.

did.unittitle: TM "Provenance" pp. 301-[362]

scopecontent.p: The last 62 pages of a corrected typescript. With a holograph version of the final page that includes a sketch by Janice Biala.

did.unittitle: TM "Provence

scopecontent.p: Complete carbon copy typescript, with minor corrections throughout in Ford's hand. The first page bears the note: "Copy corrected for Printer" and the second page gives the title as well as five other suggested provisional titles. Harvey Cii(29)

did.unittitle: Printed "Provence" Notices

scopecontent.p: A notice of "Provence" by Lewis Gannett in his colum "Books and Things" in the "New York Herald Tribune", March 21, 1935; and a review of the book by Katherine Woods in the "New York Herald Tribune Books", March 24, 1935.

did.unittitle: Q-R
TM "Que Pensez-Vous de la France?"

scopecontent.p: Copy of an article that was later published in "L'Intrasigeant", 2 (Jan.5, 1934). Harvey D379.

did.unittitle: Printed "Que Pensez-Vous de la France?" clipping

scopecontent.p: Clipping of Ford's article from "L'Intransigeant".

did.unittitle: Proof "The Questions at the Well"

scopecontent.p: Proofs of an early volume of poetry. Written under the pseudonym Fenil Haig and dedicated to "Miss Elsie Martindale."

did.unittitle: AMS "The Question at the Well, with Sundry Other Verses for Notes of Music"

scopecontent.p: Manuscript of the first section of the book of verse later published as "The Questions at the Well", signed under the pseudonym Fenil Haif. With some annotations and penciled numbering in the brackets done by publisher. Contents include: "The Questions at the Well"; "The Story of Simon Pierreauford"; "Terra Sperum [also titled "The Song of the Land of Hopes"]; and "Faith and Hope," which is the collective title of the four poems "Faith in the Park," "Faith in the Parlour," "Hope in the Park," and "Hope in the Parlour."

did.unittitle: TM "Ralston Crawford's Pictures"

scopecontent.p: Draft of a short critique later printed as program notes for an exhibit of Crawford's paintings held at the Boyer Galleries, Philadelphia, March 10-30, 1937.

did.unittitle: TM "The Rash Act" Synopsis

scopecontent.p: Copy of a synopsis of Ford's novel "The Rash Act."

did.unittitle: Printed "The Rash Act" Review

scopecontent.p: Unsigned review of "The Rash Act," published in "The New York Times Book Review", 16-17 (mar. 12, 1933).

did.unittitle: AM "The Reformers" [An English Girl]

scopecontent.p: Almost complete manuscript of what was published in 1907 as "An English Girl". With minor corrections throughout. Harvey Ci(6)

did.unittitle: TM "Return to Yesterday" Dedication

scopecontent.p: Incomplete dedication "[to] Dr. Michael and Mrs. Eileen Hall Lake," later published in "The Rash Act:. With minor corrections in pencil and three added leaves are a typescript copy of Ford's poem "Champetre".

did.unittitle: TM "Return to Yesterday"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of parts of Ford's book, including Chapter I, titled "A Mecca for Americans" (published as "Compostella Americana"); Chapter III (including some material not published in either the English or American editions); and Chapter IV (original typescript with carbon copy). The unpublished material from Chapter III (pp. 41-44 of the manuscript) deals with the role of the arts in America.

did.unittitle: Reviews
Printed "Return to Yesterday" Reviews

scopecontent.p: Two reviews of Ford's book, one by Peter Monro Jack of "The New York Times Book Review" (Jan. 24, 1932) and one by Lawrence Price of the "University of California Chronicle", XXXI, 169-171 (Jan. 1933).

did.unittitle: Printed "Dumas, The Incredible Marquis" Review

scopecontent.p: A review by Ford, entitled "Salute to Adventure," on the subject of a book about Alexandre Dumas. From an unidentified periodical.

did.unittitle: TM "Joseph Conrad" Review

scopecontent.p: Incomplete carbon copy of a review by Ford, for the periodical "Time & Tide", of Edward Crankshaw's "Joseph Conrad: Some Aspects of the Art of the Novel". See Box 12, Folder 13 for another top copy with the first page.

did.unittitle: TM "My Old World" Review

scopecontent.p: Typescript copy of Ford's review of Abbe Ernest Dimnet's book published in the "New York Harald Tribune Books" 4, Mar. 31, 1935.

did.unittitle: TM "Paris in Profile Review

did.unittitle: Printed "Rhyme and Metre, or Vers Libre" Proofs

scopecontent.p: Galley proof of a letter to the editor that later appeared in the July 16, 1920 issue of the "Athenaeum"; with some corrections in Ford's hand. Harvey D283.

did.unittitle: TM "Riesenberg" I

scopecontent.p: First draft of an incomplete typescript of Ford's short story, which appeared in the "English Review", April 1911; with many corrections and emendations not in Ford's hand. Harvey Ci(7)

did.unittitle: TM "Riesenberg " II

scopecontent.p: Uncorrected typescript draft that is probably a later version of "Riesenberg" I. Harvey Ci(7)

scopecontent.p: Typescript draft of Ford's short story; with revisions apparently in Ford's hand. Harvey Ci(7)

did.unittitle: AM "Ring out, Wild Bells"

scopecontent.p: Musical score, in the hand of Elsie Martindale Hueffer.

did.unittitle: AM "Ripostes"

scopecontent.p: Untitled early version of this poem, later published in the "Buckshee" sequence of 1931 and 1936. On the verso is a typescript draft of the poem "The Sailor's Wife".

did.unittitle: TM "Ripostes"

scopecontent.p: Draft version of this poem varies slightly from the text published as Poem VII of the "Buckshee" sequence. This text bears the title: "You Never Can Trust A Man When He's Out of Your Sight."

did.unittitle: AM "Romance"

scopecontent.p: Photocopy fragment of single page of the Ford-Conrad manuscript.

did.unittitle: AMS "A Romance of the Times Before Us"

scopecontent.p: Three versions (sub-folders A, B, & C) of an unpublished novel by Ford and possibly a collaborator. Versions A (1) [57 leaves] and B(2) [43 leaves] are in Ford's hand and are incomplete; version C (3) [71 leaves] is a copy of 2, probably in Elsie Martindale Hueffers' hand with corrections by Ford. Harvey Civ(2)

did.unittitle: AM "A Romance of the Times Before Us"

scopecontent.p: Text identified as corresponding to page 8 of version 3 of "A Romance of the Times Before Us"; in Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: AM "Roussynolet"

scopecontent.p: Musical composition.

did.unittitle: S-T
TM "The Saddest Story" [The Good Soldier]

scopecontent.p: First part of an incomplete and uncorrected draft of what was later published as "The Good Soldier". According to Thomas C. Mosher, in his "Note on the Text," in The World's Classics edition of "The Good Soldier" (Oxford: Oxford UP, 1990), "The forty-two page typescript from which the magazine installment ["Blast"] was printed ... follows the holograph manuscript, incorporating some, but not all, of its revisions .... The "Blast" typescript thus antedates the first and predates the second complete manuscript. The "Blast" installment contains the novel's epigraph but omits the first sentence." Harvey Ci(9b)

did.unittitle: AM &TM "The Saddes Story" [The Good Soldier]

scopecontent.p: An apparently complete manuscript of what was to become the novl "The Good Soldier", both typewritten and in various handwritings and divided into three sections Parts I-II, Part III, and Part IV) by pieces of green cord. Thomas C. Mosher ascribes the identities of the various transcribers as follows: "Most of Part I (manuscript pages 2-44 and 47-82) was written by Bridit Patmore; much of Part II (pages 141-196, 106-218, and 225-253) appears to have been written by the American Imagist poet H. D. (Hilda Doolittle); the last two chapters, less the first two typed pages (pages 342-376) look to be in the hand of H.D.'s husband, the English Imagist poet Richard Aldington.... The holograph portions of the manuscript surely represent first drafts; the typed portions may not be." Harvey Ci(91a)

did.unittitle: TM "The Saddest Story" [The Good Soldier]

scopecontent.p: Known as the "Printer's copy" this typescript draft of what was later published as "The Good Soldier" is not, according to Harvey, identical with the first English edition. With some handwritten corrections. Harvey Ci(9c)

did.unittitle: Printed "The Scaremonger. A Tale of the War Times"

scopecontent.p: Facsimile of a short story published in "The Bystander", Nov. 25, 1914.

did.unittitle: AM Notebook with scattered entries

scopecontent.p: A small pocket notebook, containing various entries, mostly addresses, memos of appointments, and phone numbers.

did.unittitle: AMS "Sea-Jealousy"

scopecontent.p: Poem, signed under the pseudonym "Fenil Haig" and with a note indicating that it was intended for publication in the "Speaker". Later it was published in "Poems for Pictures" in 1900.

did.unittitle: TM "See, They Return!"

scopecontent.p: Draft of an article published in "Esquire", June 1935, which was later revised and incorporated into Chapter 3 of Ford's book "The Great Trade Routs." With corrections throughout.

did.unittitle: TMS "Seraphina" [Romance}

scopecontent.p: Typescript of an early draft of the novel "Romance", with later became a collaboration between Ford and Joseph Conrad. With corrections in Ford's hand and lots of additions towards the end. This draft is really remote from "Romance", so that one can study the effect of Conrad upon Ford by checking parts of this typescript against it. Harvey A11(a)

did.unittitle: AMS "Serenada (Your Poet & Some Nightingales)"

scopecontent.p: Unpublished poem with miscellaneous pages, several versions of a part, and an inscription to Stella on the first page. Holograph passages of "Thus to Revisit" on the verso of some pages. Harvey Cvii(2aa)

did.unittitle: TM "Sevenfold Farewell"

scopecontent.p: Early version of the poem "The Newt"; with a second copy.

did.unittitle: TM "The Small Producer" [And His Hands Prepared]

scopecontent.p: Typescript of an essay that later appeared in the "American Mercury", XXXV (Aug. 1935). With some corrections. Harvey has noted a similarity in sentiment and phrasing to the "Great Trade Route". Harvey D388.

did.unittitle: TM "Society of the Friends of William Carlos Williams" Membership Roster

scopecontent.p: Typescript list of the group's members, with names including Sherwood Anderson, Ezra Pound, Marianne Moore, and Henry Miller. With annotations and emendations throughout.

did.unittitle: Printed "Some Do Not" Dust Jacket

scopecontent.p: Tattered fragment of the dust jacket for the second English impression. Harvey A56(c)

did.unittitle: Photo "Some Do Not" Dust Jacket

scopecontent.p: 8 x 10 color photograph of the image on the dust jacket of Ford's novel. Harvey A56(c)

did.unittitle: AM "The Song of the Land of Hopes"

scopecontent.p: Manuscript of a poem, also title "Terra Sperum", that was later published in "The Questions at the Well".

did.unittitle: AM Sonnet [Untitled}

scopecontent.p: Sonnet, written apparently for one of Ford's "bouts-rimes" parties. With end rhymes in Janice Biala's hand.

did.unittitle: AM "Sonnet [Whatever Things Future Have In Store]

scopecontent.p: Sonnet written for Violet Hunt.

did.unittitle: TM "Sooner Than be Idle"

scopecontent.p: Copy of an article, possibly unfinished. On the subject of the British reading public.

did.unittitle: AM "The Soul of London"

scopecontent.p: Fragment (pages 4 & 5) of what might be a very early version of "The Soul of London" or one of the two other books in the trilogy.

did.unittitle: TM Speech given at a fund-raising dinner for "Poetry" magazine

scopecontent.p: A speech on the subjects of poetry and the death of a Miss Monroe. With some corrections.

did.unittitle: AM "The Spirit of the People"

scopecontent.p: Incomplete manuscript of Chapter 3 of Ford's book. On verso of page 2 is a letter to Ford from H. Hamilton Fyfe of the "Daily Mirror"; on verso of pages 6-9 is a manuscript of an essay, apparently never published, "On Letters in England"; and on verso of pages 10-11 is a manuscript fragment possibly from "The Simple Life Limited." Harvey Cii(4)

did.unittitle: Printed "Stephen Crane" Proof

scopecontent.p: Author's proof of Ford's essay which appeared in "American Mercury", Jan. 1936. With minor corrections. Harvey Cii(32)

did.unittitle: Printed "Stevie" Review

scopecontent.p: Review of Thomas Beer's biography of Stephen Crane by Ford, published in "The New York Evening Post Literary Review", July 12, 1924. With second copy.

did.unittitle: AM "The Story of Simon Pierreford"

scopecontent.p: Manuscript poem published as "The Story of Simon Pierreauford" in "The Questions at the Well."

did.unittitle: AM & TM "Stripping Underwood"

scopecontent.p: Two versions of a poem: an incomplete typescript (1 leaf) and a corrected manuscript entitled "Felling Underwood:. Harvey Cvii(2)f

did.unittitle: TM "On Heaven" Studies

scopecontent.p: Copies of earlier versions of this poem entitled "Just Heaven" and "On Heaven". The final version was published in "Poetry", June 1914. With minor corrections. Harvey Ciii(8)c

did.unittitle: TM "A Sunday Morning Tragedy"

scopecontent.p: Incomplete carbon draft of an article on Thomas Hardy. One version later appeared in the "American Mercury", Aug. 1936 and another became Chapter 6 of "Portraits from Life". With corrections throughout and missing pages 3-5 and 20.

did.unittitle: AM "Synopses of Novels"

scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript of four sour synopses of novels: Item I, entitled "Bond", was later written and published as "When the Wicked Man"; Item II, entitle "Hallows End", and Item III, untitled, were apparently never developed but both are about characters in "The Good Soldier" about whom Ford felt he could write more; and Item IV entitle "After Waterloo," was written and published as "A Little Less Than Gods".

did.unittitle: TM "Synopses of Novels"

scopecontent.p: Typescript copy of the same synopses [20] with provisional titles included.

did.unittitle: TM "The Rash Act" Synopsis

scopecontent.p: Copy of a synopsis of Ford's novel "The Rash Act" (here called "As Thy Day"), written by J. T.

did.unittitle: TM Talk delivered over W.A.B.C., Sat., Dec. 19, 1936

scopecontent.p: Carbon copy of a radio talk that Ford delivered on the subject of the W.P.A.

did.unittitle: TMS "Techniques"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of an article on the writer's craft. Later published in the "Southern Review", 1 (July, 1935). With revisions apparently in Ford's hand and a note indicating the "manuscript [is] the property of Mrs. E.G. Bowen."

did.unittitle: AM "Tennyson"
did.physdesc: First draft of an essay occasioned by the death of Alfred Lord Tennyson. The final draft of the manuscript is titled "In Autumn the Fall of the Leaf."

did.unittitle: TM "That Same Poor Man"
did.physdesc: Typescript of Part I, Chapters 1-4 of a revised draft of an unpublished novel, originally titled "The Wheels of the Plough". With minor corrections throughout. On the title page is a quote from Ecclesiastes IX, 14-15, from which the revised title is derived. Harvey Civ(9)

did.unittitle: TM "That Same Poor Man"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of Part I, Chapters 5-11 of a revised draft of an unpublished novel, originally titled "The Wheels of the Plough". With minor corrections throughout. Harvey Civ(9)

did.unittitle: TM "That Same Poor Man"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of Par II, Chapters I-V of a revised draft of an unpublished novel, originally titled "The Wheels of the Plough". Typed on different typewriters and with corrections throughout. Harvey Civ(9)

did.unittitle: TM "That Same Poor Man"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of Part III, (subtitled "A Romance of Re-Construction), Chapters I-IV of a revised draft of an unpublished novel, originally titled "The Wheels of the Plough". Typed on different typewriters and with minor corrections throughout. The first page is marked with a stamp: "W.A. Bradley / 5, Rue S-Louis-en-L'Ile / Paris-IV". Harvey Civ(9)Harvey Civ(9)

did.unittitle: Photocopy "That Same Poor Man"

scopecontent.p: Copy of the entire manuscript of Ford's unpublished novel.

did.unittitle: AM "They Say the Old Kind Gods ..."

scopecontent.p: Draft of an unpublished poem. Written in pencil on a paper tablecloth.

did.unittitle: TM "Thinking Aloud"

scopecontent.p: Draft of an article "On War", possibly unpublished which was apparently to be part of a larger series of articles titled "Thinking Aloud". With minor corrections.

did.unittitle: TM "Thomas Hardy, O.M."

scopecontent.p: Draft of an article that was later published with slight revision under this title in the "New York Herald Tribune Books) Jan. 22, 1928. Typed on Two different typewriters. Article shares material in common with "A Sunday Morning Tragedy," with eventually became Chapter 6 in "Portraits from Life".

did.unittitle: AM & TM "Three Rhymes for a Child"

scopecontent.p: Drafts of poems, including a typescript of the three poems, "Seven Shepherds", "To Julia (Who Shall be a Poet)" (both of which were published in "New Poems"), and "Flight into Egypt" (7 leaves); a typescript of variations of "Flight into Egypt" (5 leaves); and a typescript (5 leaves) and manuscript (4 leaves) of "Lyra Domestica".

did.unittitle: AM "The Three-Ten"

scopecontent.p: Draft of poem, later published in "Songs from London", 1910. With a few corrections and with minor variations from the final version in the first stanza, and major variations in the second. Harvey Ciii(4)b

did.unittitle: AMS & TM "Thus to Revisit"

scopecontent.p: Incomplete manuscript and typescript of Ford's book. Date stamped on first page "June 7, 1920" and with corrections and emendations throughout. Parts of this book appeared in the "English Review" and the "Dial", beginning in July, 1920 and the book itself appeared in 1921. Harvey Cii(10)

did.unittitle: AM "Thus to Revisit" Note and Possible Appendix

scopecontent.p: Copy of H.G. Wells" "Letter to the Editor" in the Aug. 1920 issue of the "English Review" entitled "A Footnote to Hueffer", and a note by Ford concerning the possibility of making that article an appendix to "Thus to Revisit".

did.unittitle: Printed "Thus to Revisit" Review

scopecontent.p: Copy of one in a series of articles published in the "Piccadilly Review", bearing no resemblance to the later serialization, "Thus to Revisit", in the "English Review" and "Dial" nor to the book bearing that title. In this article, Ford critiques Max Beerbohm's "Seven Men" and W. H. Hudson's "Birds in Town and Village". Harvey D278.

did.unittitle: AM "Times" marriage advertisement

scopecontent.p: Note to be sent to the "Times" announcing Ford's marriage to Elsie Martindale. On stationary with the British Museum seal.

did.unittitle: AMS "To Petronella at Sea"

scopecontent.p: Poem, written by Ford in pencil.

did.unittitle: TM "To Violet Hunt, Poet"

scopecontent.p: Poem, inviting Violet Hunt to attend a contest of poetry-writing to be held at Ford's home on April 4, 1909.

did.unittitle: AM "Tomorrow!"

scopecontent.p: Partial dramatization of Conrad's short story which was called "One Day More." In Ford's hand. Harvey Ci(3)

did.unittitle: TM "Towards A History of English Literature"

scopecontent.p: Incomplet carbon copy typescript of an unpublished critical work. With two copies of some chapters and additions and emendations throughout. Harvey Cvi(3)

did.unittitle: TM "Towards Tomorrow"

scopecontent.p: Earlier typescript draft of Ford's book "It was the Nightingale", with was published in 1933. A few corrections throughout. Harvey Civ(28)

did.unittitle: AM & TM "Towton Field"

scopecontent.p: Poem, apparently unpublished. With a complete version of 5 leaves in Ford's hand and an incomplete version with 1 leaf of typescript. With corrections throughout. Harvey Civ(2)c

did.unittitle: AM Transcriptions of some Ford manuscripts and letters owned by Lord Stow Hill

scopecontent.p: Complete and incomplete transcripts of manuscripts and letters by Ford written by Arthur and Rosemary Mizener.

did.unittitle: AM "The Tribulations of Tolputt"

scopecontent.p: Incomplete manuscript of a short story, an earlier version of which was titled "The Troubles of Tolputt".

did.unittitle: TM Tributes and Comments

scopecontent.p: Typed list of quotes from Sinclair Lewis, Hendrick Van Loon, H.G. Wells, Hugh Walpole, and Rebecca West. The quotes come from letters to Ford and from the book jacket of the American edition of "The Good Soldier".

did.unittitle: TM "Tristia"

scopecontent.p: Poem sequence, with some poems in several versions and with many corrections in Ford's hand. Some poems are earlier, variant versions of poems published in "On Heaven", and some are unpublished.

did.unittitle: AM "The Troubles of Tolputt"

scopecontent.p: Manuscript of an earlier version of a short story later entitled "The Tribulations of Tolputt". With minor corrections throughout.

did.unittitle: Printed "Trois Jours de Permission"

scopecontent.p: Copoy of an article printed in "The Nation", Sept. 30, 1916, on the subject of a weekend leave in Paris during WWI.

did.unittitle: TM "True Love and a General Court Martial"

scopecontent.p: Incomplete draft of an unpublished war novel. With duplicates of pages, some of which have slight differences and with corrections throughout. Harvey Civ(7)

did.unittitle: TM "Two Poems in an Old Manner"

scopecontent.p: Fragment, truncated variant text of the "Aupres de ma Blonde: segment of this poem. First published in "New Poems (1922) and reprinted in the "Collected Poems (1936).

did.unittitle: U-Z, Fordiana, Memorabilia, Documents
TM "Ulysses & the Handling of Indecencies"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of an essay that appeared in the "English Review", Dec. 1922. With many excisions and corrections throughout. Harvey Civ(11)

did.unittitle: TM Untitled Short Story

scopecontent.p: Copy of an untitled short story about a maker of violin varnish. With a note in Janice Biala's hand that states "published". See Box 15, Folder 5.5 for what appears to be a longer, variant version of this manuscript.

did.unittitle: AM Untitled Short Story or Chapter from an Unpublished Novel

scopecontent.p: Manuscript of an unpublished piece of fiction about a young woman named Sarah and a Dominican friar, which stylistically bears a resemblance to "A Romance of the Times Before Us."

did.unittitle: TM "Vanellus Cristatus"

scopecontent.p: Uncorrected typescript of a poem, apparently unpublished. Harvey Cvii(2)g

did.unittitle: AM "The Verses for Notes of Music"

scopecontent.p: Manuscript of verses, partially published in "The Questions at the Well:; with two title pages and with corrections throughout. Contents include: "A Dialogue," "L'Envoi," "Faith, Hope & Charity," "A Song of Seed's Fate" fragment, "L'Envoi Dedicatory," "Hammock Song," "An October Burden" TM, "In Contempt of Palmistry," "A Song of Seed's Fate," "A Little Comfort for a Child," "Spinning Song," "In Memoriam E.M.B.," "Travellers' Tales," "Moonlit Midnight," " River Song," "In Tenebris," and "Hope in the Parlour."

did.unittitle: AMS "Wagner Educationally Considered"

scopecontent.p: An incomplete manuscript on the subject of Wagner, written as "an accompaniment to the Boyreuth Festival: and signed under the pseudonym of "Hewrman Ritter". With 2 leaves of unidentified manuscript on the back: "it was eagerly accepted by the publishers...".

did.unittitle: AM "Waking Song"

scopecontent.p: Manuscript of a poem, inspired by the bombing of some convents along the Somme river during WWI. With a fragment of "A solis ortus cardine" written on verso.

did.unittitle: TMS "The Wall: Things Seen in U.S.A."

scopecontent.p: Typescript of an essay, much of which was later incorporated in Sections 3 & 4 of the "Great Trade Route, Woyage Outwards". With a note indicating the manuscript "the property of Mrs. E.G. Bowen" and with revisions apparently in Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: AM "War--the Mind"

scopecontent.p: Signed with the pseudonym "Miles Ignotus". Manuscript draft of Part II, subtitled "The Enemy," of an essay, some part of which was posthumously published in "Esquire" magazine, Dec. 1980 {see Box 2, Folder 6] in an article titled "Arms and the Mind." Also, see Ford's manuscript "A Day of Battle" [Box 3, Folder 22] for what might be the first part of this manuscript.

did.unittitle: TM "War and the Mind.II The Enemy"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of the second part of an essay, posthumously published as "Arms and the Mind". Signed "Miles Ignotus" and with revisions apparently in Ford's hand. See Box 2, Folder 6; Box 3, Folder 22; and Box 26, Folder 8 for earlier and later drafts of this essay as well as its first part "A Day of Battle."

did.unittitle: TM "Weather"

scopecontent.p: Copy of a possibly unpublished article on the subject of weather. Typed on two different typewriters.

did.unittitle: TM [What do Doctors know?]

scopecontent.p: Typescript of an incomplete, untitled essay, on the subject of the science of medicine.

did.unittitle: AM "The Wheels of the Plough"

scopecontent.p: Incomplete manuscript of an unpublished novel, later titled "That Same Poor Man". Part I, Chapters I-III (77 leaves) are in Stella Bowen's hand; Part I, Chapters X-XIII & Part II, Chapters I-V are in Ford's hand (200 leaves); and the rest is missing. Harvey Civ(6)

did.unittitle: AM "Trio: When Runnels Begin to Leap and Sing"

scopecontent.p: Musical composition with corrections in pencil and a note "Correct for next time." See Box 12, Folder 16 for the lyrics of this composition written simply as verse.

did.unittitle: TM "...When that I was a Little, Little Boy..."

scopecontent.p: Copy of an essay on the subject of social conventions and prudery. With one holograph correction in Ford's hand. Second copy of pages 5-7.

did.unittitle: TM "When the Wicked Man" [Notterdam}

scopecontent.p: Fragmentary original version of Ford's novel, here titled "Notterdam". With excisions and corrections in Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: TM "When the Wicked Man"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of Part I, Chapters I-III, of Ford's novel, still titled "Notterdam". With numerous corrections in Ford's hand and three copies of an illustrated programme, atop which Ford has penciled "Notterdam".

did.unittitle: TM "When the Wicked Man"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of Part II, Chapters I-III of Ford's novel, still titled "Notterdam". With numerous corrections in Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: TM "When the Wicked Man"

scopecontent.p: Typescript of Part III, Chapters I-IV & Part IV, Chapters I-IV of Ford's novel. Still titled "Notterdam" With numerous corrections in Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: TDS "When the Wicked Man" Contract

scopecontent.p: Carbon copy of the book contract for Ford's novel, still tentatively titled "Notterdam". Signed by Ford as well as a representative of the publishers Horace Liveright, Inc.

did.unittitle: TD "When the Wicked Man" Royalty Statement

scopecontent.p: Royalty statement from Liveright Inc., Publishers concerning the money owed from Ford's novel.

did.unittitle: Printed "When the Wicked Man" Reviews

scopecontent.p: Reviews of Ford's novel for "The New York Herald Tribune," "The Mirror," "The New York Times," " New York Evening Post," "Chicago Tribune," "Philadelphia Ledger," "The Outlook" and "The Shanghai Times".

did.unittitle: TM "When the Wicked Man" Synopsis, List of Characters

scopecontent.p: Three versions of a synopsis of Ford's novel and a list of its characters. An original typescript with corrections, a revised version with some corrections and a carbon copy of the final version.

did.unittitle: Printed "The Wind's Quest"

scopecontent.p: Leaf torn from the "Torch", 1891, with Ford's written note indicating that this was the first thing he ever wrote. On the verso is the beginning of a song verse in Ford's hand, with four bars of music.

did.unittitle: TM "Women and Men"

scopecontent.p: Complete typescript of Ford's book of essays, with a few minor corrections. Harvey Cii(2). [See Harvey A54 for evidence that dates the manuscript well before its 1923 publishing date.]

did.unittitle: AM "The Wood-Haunter's Dream"

scopecontent.p: Poem, not in Ford's hand and possibly not by Ford. Harvey Cvii(2)k

did.unittitle: No folder 17
Printed "The Work of William Harrison Coleshaw"

scopecontent.p: Photocopy of an article by Ford, published in "The Artist", Sept., 1897.

did.unittitle: TM "Working with Conrad"

scopecontent.p: Single manuscript page of an article, the complete text of which appeared in "The Yale Review," Summer, 1929. With many corrections and emendations in Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: AM & TM "The Year of Last Omens"

scopecontent.p: Poem, the first three sections of which is handwritten and the fourth section is typed. Corrections throughout in Ford's hand. Harvey Cvii(2)i.

did.unittitle: TM "Years After"

scopecontent.p: Carbon copy of an apparently unpublished short essay commemorating those British soldiers who died in WWI. Harvey Civ(10)

did.unittitle: Removed
Printed "Young America Abroad"

scopecontent.p: Article, published in "The Saturday Review of Literature" on the subject of the exodus of American writers to Europe.

did.unittitle: TM "The Young D.H."

scopecontent.p: Draft carbon copy of an essay about D.H. Lawrence, which appeared in one version in the "American Mercury" XXXVIII, June, 1936, and in another as chapter five of "Portraits from Life."

did.unittitle: AM & TM "The Young Lovell"

scopecontent.p: Incomplete, corrected holograph and typescript version of Ford's novel [277 leaves], and a typescript of Part II with the corrections made which had been indicated on the earlier draft [118 leaves]. Harvey Civ(8).

did.unittitle: AM & TM "Young Man's Road Song"

scopecontent.p: Two versions of an apparently unpublished poem, a complete, untitled holograph copy and an incomplete titled typescript copy. Harvey Civ(2)a.

did.unittitle: AM "Young Wife's Song"

scopecontent.p: Poem, apparently unpublished. In Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: DS Agreement signed by Ford and Stella Bowen after their breakup

scopecontent.p: Two copies of a legal document signed by Ford and Stella Bowen, outlining the terms of their separation. The second copy, in purple ink belonged to Bowen.

did.unittitle: DS Bank Draft

scopecontent.p: Bank draft for five pounds, signed by Ford for John Galsworthy.

did.unittitle: DS Check

scopecontent.p: Check for 125 pounds, signed by Ford for Theodore Watts-Dutton.

did.unittitle: DS Check

scopecontent.p: Check for 2 pounds, 10 shillings, signed by Ford for J.W. Lewis.

did.unittitle: DS Check

scopecontent.p: Check for 137 francs, signed by Ford for Captain F.G. Bonham-Carter.

did.unittitle: TDS "It was the Nightingale" Contract

scopecontent.p: Contract between Esther Gwendolyn Bowen

did.unittitle: D "The Nature of a Crime" Contract

scopecontent.p: Ford's carbon of the contract signed by Elliot Holt with an appended note concerning the terms and conditions for the re-issue of Ford's novel.

did.unittitle: TDS "Vanity Fair" Contract

scopecontent.p: Ford's copy of a contract that specifies the he will write eight articles for "Vanity Fair", signed by a representative of Conde Nast.

did.unittitle: AD Description of property

scopecontent.p: A list of various properties owned by Ford as well as the income to be derived from them. In Ford's hand.

did.unittitle: ADS Passport for Ford Madox Brown

scopecontent.p: A passport of Brown's issued in Belgium in Sept. 1945, 2 leaves stamped in various countries.

did.unittitle: DS Passport

scopecontent.p: A passport of Ford's issued on November 15, 1932 in Marseilles.

did.unittitle: D Petition for restitution of conjugal rights for Elsie Hueffer

scopecontent.p: A citation issued to Ford by Elsie Hueffer, necessitating his appearance in divorce court.

did.unittitle: AD Sales receipt for the Bungalow, Winchelsea

scopecontent.p: Receipt of the sale of Ford's property to Mr. Harris for 641+ pounds.

did.unittitle: DS Temporary passport

scopecontent.p: Temporary passport issued to Ford on Nov. 1, 1932.

did.unittitle: Printed FORDIANA

scopecontent.p: Collection of various newspaper and magazine clippings by or about Ford. Includes photographs of the author, reviews and mentions of his works as well as news of the escalating violence in Germany in the 1930's.

did.unittitle: Series II. Outgoing correspondence

processinfo.p: In the cases where there is a lot of correspondence to one recipient, the box numbers may be out of sequence.

did.unittitle: Series III. Incoming correspondence and manuscripts by others

scopecontent.p: This series includes both correspondence and manuscripts written by other people.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by sender or author.

processinfo.p: In the cases where there is a lot of material from one person, the box numbers may be out of sequence.

scopecontent.p: London; My dear Lady. Many thanks. It is distressing that we are already took for Monday night. [Violet Hunt's copy.]

did.unittitle: Bennett, Arnold ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; Just come in. I wrote to F.M.H. [Ford] this morning that our first free moment is Wednesday night, [Violet Hunt's copy]

did.unittitle: Bennett, Arnold ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: London My dear lady. Mill remerciments. We cannot, unfortunately, accept night engagements. [ Violet Hunt's copy]

did.unittitle: Bennett, Arnold ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; Thank you. Blague a poart, it really is difficult to get seats, especially as this is a jubilee production. [Violet Hunt's copy]

did.unittitle: Bennett, Arnold ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; My dear lady. I reply to your letter as Marguerite is still so neuralgic after influenza that she can't [Violet Hunt's copy]

did.unittitle: Bennett, Arnold ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; My dear Violet, Many thanks for "More Tales of the Uneasy," which I am soon going to read. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Violet, I am glad to have your letter. This is just to acknowledge it. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dear Stella, That seems to be all right. The person Herbert Gorman particularly recommends

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice TL[copy] to Stella Bowen

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice TL[copy] to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: Toulon; Dear Stella, About Julie: as far as I know she has been with the Marcoussis since the 18th or 19th

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice TL[copy] to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: Toulon; Dear Stella, The answers are as follows in the order as you ask the questions

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice TL[copy] to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: Toulon; Dear Stella, I am afraid there is not the slightest chance of Ford's being able to write a story

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice TL[copy] to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: Toulon; Dear Stella, You can do what you like about placing "Provence". All that Ford asks is that the publisher should be reputable

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice TL[copy] to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: Toulon; Dear Stella: I forwarded you yesterday the typescript of Ford's novel VIVE LE ROY

scopecontent.p: [Paris]Dear Stella, Ford has now finished his book. Will you please return the chapter you have

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice TL[copy] to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [Paris] Dear Stella, We are still here and shall be until the 4th July. Our plans are pretty well maturing

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice TL[copy] to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: Toulon; Dear Stella, The change in the order of the books is just a friendly agreement [Julian Loewe papers]

scopecontent.p: [Olivet?] Dear Stella, Ford has been forced by our very severe necessities to try to mortgage his Mr. Croyd novel,

scopecontent.p: [Paris] Dear Stella, Thank you so much for your letter. Believe me, I do know that Ford was "your man" too. [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: New York; Dear Stella, I sent off the books of articles to Unwin's last week. Will you arrange for terms [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: New York; Dear Stella, I am so relieved to have heard from you. From here everything looks so terrifying [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York] Dear Stella, I can't tell you how glad I am to have heard from you both. I have been trying to write you for ages [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York?] Dear Stella, Thank you for your very nice letter - and I'm glad mine of the 15th Sept. at last caught up with you. [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York]; Dear Stella, In a letter I received this morning from Douglas Goldring he says [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York?] Dear Stella/ Thank you very much for the cable which came 3 days ago & your letter before that, [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York?] Dear Stella/ Thanks for yours of the 30th. I had myself come to the same conclusion about Goldring's book [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York?] Dear Stella/ I am enclosing copies of two letters sent to Unwin & one from them to me [no enclosures with this] [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York?] Dear Stella, I am absolutely delighted by the news ref. The 5th Queen and awed by the amount of the advance. [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York?] Dear Stella, I received your second note ref. the bibliography after I had already written the enclosed letter, [Julian Loewe papers]

scopecontent.p: [New York?] Dear Stella/ It's alr3eight - I'm too cynical to think we're all about to get rich [Written on verso of AL[fragment], [n.d.] that Bowen wrote to Biala] [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York?] Dear Stella/ Another little headache, which perhaps you can solve. New Directions, which is a small non commercial publishing house [Julian Loewe papers]

scopecontent.p: Peconic, L.I.; Dear Stella/ I am very concerned to hear that your blood pressure has shot up [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

did.unittitle: Biala, Janice ALS to Stella Bowen

scopecontent.p: [New York?] My dear dear Stella/ Your letter is full of interesting news and gave me much pleasure. [Julian Loewe papers]

did.unittitle: Bowen, Stella TL[transcripts] to Ford

scopecontent.p: [These transcripts were made by Julia Loewe for a book of Ford's and Bowen's letters which was never completed. Some of the transcripts are edited versions of the originals. In many cases Cornell has the original furnished by Julian Loewe; in many cases Cornell has the copy Bowen made. A few of the transcripts are the only copy Cornell has; although in some cases Cornell has all three. These can be found in Box 47 and Box 47a as they were added to the collection at different times.]

scopecontent.p: Penshurst; Dear Mr. Ford, Apparently you are the kindest person in the world, too.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst; Dear Mr. Ford, Do you mind my writing again so soon? I take it that you are in Provence

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, Your letter was a delight. How you manage to do it I can't guess, neither of us can.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, It was good to hear from you again, and thank you.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, Your so kind note came straight at me from Paris like a sudden dazzling ray

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford & Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Penshurst; Dear and kind friends, This should have been written yesterday (I was trying to write it in my head all the way home

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, Thank you so much for your letter about the Duckworth confusion.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, I wrote to Duckworth, as I said, and an answer has come.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, Something silly happened to your last letter on its way here, and it came to me about a month late.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, The newspaper report of Mrs. Ford's lecture (which so far I haven't had a moment to read properly)

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward ALS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, I have heard from BÃ©haine, who is delighted at the tought of your doing a preface.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, There is no need to say how wretched we are at the news of your illness.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, I suppose there's nothing in the world I value more than your approval of my work.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, The proofs have come at last, a week after they were promised,

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, Indeed I got your preface (and sent it to Unwins at once to send to Greenslet).

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Penshurst, Dear Mr. Ford, It was good to hear from you and to know where you are to be found.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Sandhurst; Dear Mr. Ford, I have had your last letter longer than I thought without answering it.

did.unittitle: Crankshaw, Edward TLS & ALS to Arthur Mizener

scopecontent.p: Includes 15 letters by Crankshaw; 8 letters by Clare Crankshaw; 2 leaves of notes by Mizener; ALS to Clare Crankshaw from Lady Rosalie Mander; Mizener letters to Newnham College, Clare Crankshaw and Edward Crankshaw; and TLS to George Harris Healey from Edward Crankshaw. Dated between July 28, 1965 - May 15, 1972.[Gift of Arthur and Rosemary Mizener]

scopecontent.p: [London] Dear Miss Hunt, No. I did not know even that you knew Mrs. Moulton. Why did I never meet you

scopecontent.p: [London] Dear Miss Hunt, I think your verses better than I expected, and I expected from what several people had told me, that they would be very good indeed.

scopecontent.p: [London] You have no right whatever to telegraph to me in that way - it is a threatening telegram, and I resent it. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [London] my cure here with exercises for the lungs and inhalations, which are doing me great good. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Crawfurd, Oswald John Frederick TL[copy] to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [London] Bad-Ems; My dear Violet, You wrote me such complaining querolous letters taht I could not, though I wanted, answer them. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [London] My dear Violet, I have been a good deal cerne lately - chiefly monetary. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: New York; Dear Mr. Ford:- The American Mercury is Buying HANDS OFF THE ARTS. Although we tried to get $250, they implied that you had practically agreed on $200 [Singed C.R. Everitt]

scopecontent.p: New York; Dear Mr. Ford: I am sure I don't need to tell you how useful and intelligent A HISTORY OF OUR OWN TIMES is, [Signed C.R. Everitt]

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Janice Biala

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Janice Biala

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Janice Biala

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: [Monteagle?] My dearest Ford: I see now that it was indescribably stupid in me not to know that it would please you

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: [Clarksbille] Dearest Ford: I expected you would write something mighty good about "Penhally"

scopecontent.p: Dearest Ford: It is already late to be sending you wishes for a merry Christmas

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: Paris; Dearest Ford: We have just got in -- it is so much easier to drive into Paris than it is to drive into New York

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Ford

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Ford

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Ford & Janice Biala

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Ford

did.unittitle: Gordon, Caroline TLS to Ford

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dearest Alfred, S[ilva] much better here. She is to be kept in her room till she goes to Whitby

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dearest Alfred/ I think we shall come on Monday next if all be well.

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... A hand that [torn] more like a casually purchased bunch of bananas than anything else. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dearest Violet/ All right about the parties. The M A's are coming very fairly [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine AL[fragment] to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... Dearer if you ask for chops if you buy a small piece of the joint [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine AL[fragment] to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... Don't worry yourself about the price of things - get all the experience you can and do for the best [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... Frank instead of your father. I hoped he would invite him & C. Barnes [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine AL[fragment]S to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... friendly with him from staying so long in the house with him [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dear V. I am coming home tomorrow - Tuesday in the afternoon. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine AL[fragment]S to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dearest V. I am glad you are happy and hope you will enjoy yourself yourself [sic] & get strong. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dearest V. I am not sure now that S[ilva] will leave home so soon as we expected. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: My dearest Violet & Venice not forgetting Sylvia/ I am so glad when I get your dear little letters only you have made Papa idle [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt, Sylvia Hunt [Fogg Elliot] & Venice Hunt [Benson]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dearest children/ I am very anxious to hear that you have reaches W. safely. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear Violet/ I am very glad you have had a bath. I was going to write and tell you to get one. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dearest V. I can't see to write much but must send a line to tell you not to give the cat medicine [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine AL[fragment] to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... I don't think S[ylvia] was keeping anything back from me & pretending to be better than she really was [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine AL to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dearest V. I enclose Bry's letter - If you think he had rather send the book will you get your Papa to direct it to him [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: Folkestone; My dearest Violet/ I got here safely after what seemed a very long journey -[Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dear V. I have no time to write or think but I send a word to say how sorry I am about your hand -- [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dearest Violet/ I have very little time to write & can best send little scratches when moving about or waiting for trains. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear Violet/ I hope you are all well. Take great care of yourself and don't make yourself ill with eating fast [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dear V. I hope you are taking care of that lump. If it gets large see a doctor [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear Violet/ I would have like to have written to you yesterday but was prevented by numbers of people coming in [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dearest V. I think you will find that S[ylvia] will send a little note with this. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dear V. & S. If you have not paid away the postal orders send them here for Miss Smith would be glad of them[Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dearest V. Invitation to write very nice but I have not an idea in my head & have no time to do more [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; My dear V. Just a line to say that I hope if you cook at all you will take great care not to wear loose aprons [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dear V. Just a small line in great haste to say that I hear diptheria is bad at Eton [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... less of the lodgings. We must be there for Mr. Maccoli's first lecture. I forget whether it is on the 3rd or 2nd. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine AL[fragment] to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... met Orion home once or twice & liked him - He talked well & had known everyone of his own best time [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine AL[fragment] to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear V. Of course you have not taken Mrs. C's without having first settled with Mrs. S. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine AL[Fragment]S to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: ... Saturday we might go to Dunham on Tuesday - I expect we should want Monday in town [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dear V. & A. Silvia is all right and would be better still only we had a nurse she hated [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear Violet/ Silvia is doing very well & so is the baby and I am happy to say the nurse arrived early this morning. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dear V. Tell me all you are doing and do not take rooms this time for young men who may not want them [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... That niece of Mrs. Alexanders was at the Palgraves - [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dearest V. The [?] parted for Paris without wanting to go particularly [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dearest A. & V.V. had much better write to S at once. It will do her good. [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear Violet/ Walton has just gone. His is one of the 15 chosen players who are going round to overcome [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear V. We are all wrong again here. S did too much yesterday morning and in the afternoon Mrs. Mason came and stayed too long [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear V. We have had an awful time ever since baby was born - [Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Hunt, Margaret Raine ALS to Violet Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... What do you think about it? I send a list of visitors to you - pencil show who are asked, [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear V. You need not send any reports of business matters or public companies here. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear V. You shall do as you like about coming home but you are well out of being here - [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: London; My dear Brown. I shall be and Edith also will be very happy to dine with you

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] My dear Mrs. Hunt. I am think I am free on Thursday - if you will excuse my being so late as 7.

scopecontent.p: Jerusalem; Dear Mrs. Hunt- Pray excuse the smallness of this note in answer to yours

did.unittitle: Hunt, William Holman ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Dear Mrs. Hunt- I shall hope to join your party on Tuesday next.

did.unittitle: Hunt, William Holman ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt. It is an inexpressable advantage to me to have the use of your studio.

did.unittitle: Hunt, William Holman ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt. I have been away at Oxford where I was detained longer than I had intended to be

scopecontent.p: London; My dear Mrs. Hunt. As I am going to Winchester this evening I shall not have the opportunity I had looked to of calling upon you

scopecontent.p: London; My dear Mrs. Hunt. I called upon you about a fortnight ago but was unfortunate to speak according to my intentions

did.unittitle: Loewe, Esther Julia Madox ALS to Ford

did.unittitle: Loewe, Esther Julia Madox TLS to Arthur Mizener

scopecontent.p: [n.p.]Now dear, please answer me at one... O my feed & horsey.. I've lost 3 little pound that were to pay me rent here [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] Seen no mutual friends for some time. Gosse came here yesterday & Tebbs came here one day last week. [Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: [n.p.] ... What influence has been to me the dire loses of friends, is beyond realization. It was quite uncanny [ Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt, Lawson & I will onoly be too happy to see you on Sunday & are much obliged for your kind invitation. [ Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt, I am sorry to be so late in replying to your very kind letter -- [ Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Marzials, Theophilus Julius Henry ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; My dear Mrs. Hunt, I have been wishing to write to you for a long time, but remembering my fatal promise Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Marzials, Theophilus Julius Henry ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt, Just one very rapid little word to say that I was from home yesterday or should have sooner [ Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Marzials, Theophilus Julius Henry ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt, If you only knew how I have tried to write to you all this week [ Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Marzials, Theophilus Julius Henry ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; My dear Mrs. Hunt, I had made many vows not to some & see you for many weeks thinking me of Solomon's [ Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt, I left you in a very melancholy state last Sunday [ Violet Hunt papers]

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt, I went to see Mr. Hunt's pictures & thought they looked most exquisitely lovely -- [ Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Marzials, Theophilus Julius Henry ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt, You were very sweet, both of you yesterday; [ Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Marzials, Theophilus Julius Henry ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt, I can't come I am grieved to say this evening as I am going to dine [ Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Marzials, Theophilus Julius Henry ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mrs. Hunt, How are you & the painter husband? I have been several times to gaze at your house [ Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Marzials, Theophilus Julius Henry ALS to Margaret Raine Hunt

scopecontent.p: London; How awful, you must come. What an idea. It will be very interesting. [ Violet Hunt papers]

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: The idea of Alain's not going to see that doctor! You'd think he'd do it just not to embarass me, wouldn't you?

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: You're right, I am in a dilemma between my loyalty to you and my loyalty to Cornell

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: I was just about to pick up the electric telephone this morning -- well, this afternoon,

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: Well, hell, I'm sorry about all this. When Mr. McCarthy told me what he was writing you,

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: How marvelous! How delightful! To think that we have brought it off to everyone's satisfaction.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: I cannot remember -- such has been the confusion of these last weeks -- whether or not I told you

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: The prompt reply, see, as guaranteed in our last. And let it begin by my saying how much I appreciate the kindness

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Brighton; Dear Biala: Well, nuts to you and these cracks about how scholars might find MacShane entertaining.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Biala: The specific purpose of this letter is to say Merry Christmas to you both from R and me --

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Biala: I guess I thought of everything except that you have lost the address: stupid of me.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: It is good of you to hope that your letter would catch us on the beach at Little Compton,

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: What an absolutely glorious Christmas card! Do you think perhaps the sunlight was better in the 18th C.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: You owe me a letter, Bud, not me you. However, the truth is that I was just on the verge of swallowing my pride

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: I think your plan about the pictures of Ford for the National Gallery is admirable --

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: Many, many thanks for your letter; I can imagine the difficulties of writing such a letter

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: First of all about the papers. I am sorry Alain has to have another operation.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: Delphic oracle, hell; I can't even get my own income tax straight.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: The tombstone in Aldington cemetary reads: TO THE DEAR MEMORY OF ELSIE HUEFFER

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: I am terribly unhappy that my book has distressed you as it has but I am very grateful to you

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Janice: I'm so sorry to have been slow in answering your last, good letter. We've been having a bad time of it around here;

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: Before your last letter reached me, I had revised everything in the book -- in proof -- that you had specifically mentioned

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Janice Biala

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Biala: I hope you have by this time received your copy of THE SADDEST STORY. I urged them to send copies to you

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to William H. Bond

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Mr. Bond: I have just had a letter from Mrs. Katharine Lamb, the daughter of Ford Madox Ford,

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to The British Museum

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Sirs: I wonder if it would be possible for me to obtain photo copies of the following items

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Susan Jenkins Brown

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Mrs. Brown: Many thanks for your very generous letter. I shall certainly take advantage

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Miss Burne

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Miss Burne: I hope it is not importunate of me to be writing you about the Violet Hunt papers

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy,fragment] to Margaret Cole

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Mrs. Cole: I am beginning to feel it is almost unfair to answer your letters because then you feel you have to answer me

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Margaret Cole

scopecontent.p: [Ithaca] Dear Mrs. Cole: Thank you very much for offering to allow me to interrup your Christmas visit with your daughter

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Margaret Cole

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Mrs. Cole: My wife and I are planning to come to England this summer; we shall reach London around August 1st

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Editor, "Daily Mail"

scopecontent.p: [Ithaca] Dear Sirs: Let me begin with an apology for this request; I would not make it if I had not exhausted the resources

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Edward Davison

scopecontent.p: [Ithaca] Dear Mr. Davison: I make bold to assail you quite out of the blue in this way because Peter has encouraged me to do so

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Gerald Duckworth & Co.

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Sirs: I am at work on a biography of Ford Madox Ford and it is possible to deduce from the Ford papers

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Leon Edel

scopecontent.p: [Ithaca] Dear Leon: I am just back from two weeks in Florida; hence the delay; but I don't mention the trip unless I have to

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Leon Edel

scopecontent.p: [Ithaca] Dear Leon: Many thanks for the transcripts of the James letters. I was particularly pleased to have the ones from the Barrett Collection.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Leon Edel

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Leon: There is probably no novelty to you in what follows, but since I came across these items at Texas

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Elliot & Fry

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Sirs: I am at work on a biography of the novelist Ford Madox Ford, who called himself Ford Madox Hueffer before 1915.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Florence Wynne Finch

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Mrs. Finch: How very kind of you to write me so intelligently and informatively about Arthur Marwood:

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Margaret Flack

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Miss Flack: I have been attempting to call you this morning but there appears to be something wrong with our telephone

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Jeanne R. Foster

scopecontent.p: [Ithaca] Dear Mrs. Foster: I have been working for four or five years on a biography of Ford Madox Ford

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to David Garnett

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mr. Garnett: I am in England working on a biography of Ford Madox Ford. I am of course acquainted with what you have said

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to David Garnett

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mr. Garnett: Your boat around the first of December or so would be wonderful; thank you very much.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to David Garnett

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mr. Garnett: This is very kind of you; I had hoped since you are providing all the reason, I should be able to provide the feast.

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to David Garnett

scopecontent.p: [Ithaca] Dear David: We got back from St. Paul, where we spent Christmas with our grandchildren , to find your Christmas card

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to David Garnett

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear David: How very glad I was to hear from you. I have been nursing the idea that you owed me a letter

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to David Garnett

scopecontent.p: [Ithaca] Dear David: OK, I didn't have much hope, after your last letter, about Edward's letter, but I wanted to try;

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[coppy] to Patrick Garnett

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Mr. Garnett: Two or three weeks ago I had a most interesting conversation with David Garnett about Ford Madox Ford

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Richard Garanett

scopecontent.p: [Ithaca] Dear Mr. Garnett: Since you very kindly agreed to let me look over the Ford Madox Ford papers in the possession of Darley Cumberland,

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Victor Gollancz, Ltd.

scopecontent.p: London; Dear Sirs: I am at work on a biography of Ford Madox Ford and David Harvey says in his bibliography of Ford

did.unittitle: Mizener, Arthur TL[copy] to Caroline Gordon

scopecontent.p: Ithaca; Dear Caroline: I have been plugging away since February on Ford and I have now got him to the winters of 1927-28 and 1928-29

list.head: Bound Manuscripts - cataloged individually in the Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections
list.item: Bd. Ms. 1 Ford Madox Ford and the Arts, Summer, 1989. Named "Contemp. Lit.": Galley proofs of an Issue of "Contemporary Literature" v.30, no.2; Devoted to Ford, guest editor: Joseph Wiesenfarth.
Bd. Ms 2-3+ That Same Poor Man, Circa 1928. Names Croyd I & II: Bound typed manuscript by Ford, with corrections in holograph of "That Same Poor Man", in 2 volumes, in slip case.

Bd. Ms. 4 Souvenir: Anecdote et pensee diverse ou morale de l'histoire et des pholosophe,1770. Named Diary: In unknown hand, French volume of 690 pages [pages 682-689 missing] of happenings, thoughts and philosophy in the 1770's. Arranged alphabetically, with main titles in the margins.

Bd. Ms 5 English Country or Gringoire s'en va-t-en Guerre: A Reconstructionary Tale, Circa 1927. >Named English Country: Typed manuscript by Ford of an unpublished story, thought to be renamed "No Enemy" when published. Signed by Ford on title page. In slipcase.
Bd. Ms. 6+ The Last Sowing: a Romance, 1895-1898. Named Last: Early work of Ford; first portion is in the hand of Elsie Hueffer, Ford's own hand is after p.333.
Bd. Ms. 7 The Marsden Case, Circa 1922. Named Marsden: Hand written and typed manuscript by Ford, with holographic corrections. In case, within slip case.
Bd. Ms. 8+ O Hymen, 1927. Named O Hymen: Typed manuscript by Ford, with a few holographic corrections. In slip case.
Bd. Ms. 9 The Rash Act, 1933. Named Rash: In Ford's hand, bound manuscript. In slip case.
Bd. Ms. 10++ Literary Cuttings, 1908-1909. Newspaper clippings with reviews of articles and poems from the "English Review", edited by Ford.
Bd. Ms. 11+ The Saddest Story, Circa 1914-1915. Photocopy of the manuscript of Ford's "The Saddest Story". In case.
Bd. Ms. 12+ W.H. Hudson "Some Reminiscences", Circa 1935. In Ford's hand, essay on W. H. Hudson, author, naturalist and ornithologist.
